name: Litigation
title: Certification Crossroads: Supreme Court Declines Review, Deepening Circuit Split on Opt-In ...
authors: Stephen Fox, Jonathan Clark, Graydon Cowan, Jennifer Risberg
description:
Fifth and Sixth Circuit Approach Like the Seventh Circuit, the Fifth and Sixth Circuits have moved away from the traditional Lusardi standard.
The Supreme Court Denies Certiorari in Richards In Richards, Eli Lilly submitted a petition for certiorari—which was joined by several amici—arguing that it was critical the Supreme Court resolve the growing circuit split in class certification standards.
Richards will now head back to the district court, which will likely apply the new Seventh Circuit standard to determine class certification.
What Employers Need to Know The Supreme Court’s refusal to hear argument in Richards leaves a variance in class certification standards across jurisdictions.
Until the Supreme Court provides definitive guidance, employers must remain aware of the disparate standards and procedures that accompany collective action lawsuits across the country.
text:
On January 12, 2026, the U.S. Supreme Court declined to address a deepening circuit split about the process for certifying collective class actions under the Age Discrimination in Employment Act (“ADEA”) and the Fair Labor Standards Act (“FLSA”). As a result, uncertainty persists for employers and employees alike, with federal courts adopting a range of standards.

Historical Class Certification Standard

Both Rule 23 class actions and FLSA section 216(b) collective actions allow employees to bring suit on behalf of others who are “similarly situated.” Section 216(b) mandates employee-plaintiffs opt-in to the lawsuit, which requires courts to approve and oversee the circulation of class notice to potential plaintiffs. The same process applies to ADEA class actions. In Hoffman-La Roche, Inc. v. Sperling (1989), the U.S. Supreme Court authorized the sending of notice of a FLSA collective action to potential opt-in plaintiffs so long as that notice is neutral, timely and accurate. Following the Supreme Court’s holding in Hoffman-La Roche, most federal courts adopted a plaintiff-friendly, two-step analysis articulated in Lusardi v. Xerox Corp. Under the Lusardi approach, plaintiffs who demonstrate that employees are “similarly situated” based on a “modest factual showing” achieve conditional certification.

Conditional certification permits district courts to oversee the circulation of notice to potential class action members. Courts then consider final certification or decertification at a later point in the case. Practically, this lenient standard has increased class sizes and created pressure for employers to settle early, before incurring the time and expense associated with the seemingly perfunctory “conditional” certification process and, thereafter, the final, evidence-based class certification decision.

Seventh Circuit’s Approach

In August, the Seventh Circuit, in Richards v. Eli Lilly & Company, departed from the two-step Lusardi analysis. There, the Seventh Circuit held that district courts must consider evidence from both sides concerning whether workers are similarly situated enough to proceed together. Under the Seventh Circuit’s approach in Richards, a plaintiff must first make a threshold showing that there is a material factual dispute as to whether the proposed collective is similarly situated. Thereafter, employer/defendants may submit rebuttal evidence. Once the court determines a material dispute exists, the decision to issue notice rests on its assessment of the factual dispute before it. Overall, this standard requires more evidence than Lusardi, which can reduce the pressure employers feel to settle that has traditionally accompanied conditional certification.

Fifth and Sixth Circuit Approach

Like the Seventh Circuit, the Fifth and Sixth Circuits have moved away from the traditional Lusardi standard.

In the Fifth Circuit (Swales v. KLLM Transport Services LLC), plaintiffs must meet a more demanding one-step test, showing it is “more likely than not” that employees are similarly situated. When crafting this standard in Swales, the Fifth Circuit noted the more lenient Lusardi approach resulted in broad circulation of conditional class notice to plaintiffs who were not truly similarly situated. This was frequently used as leverage against employers to compel them to settle. Similar to the Seventh Circuit, the Fifth Circuit now requires lower courts to vet plaintiffs at the outset of litigation and consider all available evidence before authorizing class notices. This standard is far more favorable to employer/defendants.

In the Sixth Circuit (Clark v. A&L Homecare and Training Center, LLC), plaintiffs must demonstrate a “strong likelihood” that the proposed group is similarly situated. The Sixth Circuit rejected the “more likely than not” standard as too high of a bar for plaintiffs, but found the Lusardi approach too lenient. Thus, in the Sixth Circuit, a plaintiff must make a showing that goes beyond creating a genuine issue of fact, but it need not rise to the level of “more likely than not” or a “preponderance”. Accordingly, the standard of proof in the Sixth Circuit falls between Lusardi and Swales.

The Supreme Court Denies Certiorari in Richards

In Richards, Eli Lilly submitted a petition for certiorari—which was joined by several amici—arguing that it was critical the Supreme Court resolve the growing circuit split in class certification standards. Last week, however, the Supreme Court denied certiorari. Richards will now head back to the district court, which will likely apply the new Seventh Circuit standard to determine class certification.

What Employers Need to Know

The Supreme Court’s refusal to hear argument in Richards leaves a variance in class certification standards across jurisdictions. While most federal courts continue to apply the Lusardi approach—a relatively low bar for plaintiffs to obtain condition certification—recent decisions in the Fifth, Sixth, and Seventh Circuits have created stricter, more employer-friendly standards. These varying criteria will almost certainly have the strategic effect of encouraging collective action plaintiffs to file suit—if jurisdictionally possible—in circuits other than the Fifth, Sixth, and Seventh. Until the Supreme Court provides definitive guidance, employers must remain aware of the disparate standards and procedures that accompany collective action lawsuits across the country. Employers seeking more information may contact Sheppard Mullin’s Labor and Employment team for additional insights and strategies.

name: Human Rights
title: Federal Agent Fires Gun During Immigration Operation in L.A. Area, Officials Say
authors: Jill Cowan, Orlando Mayorquín, Johnny Diaz, www.nytimes.com, jill-cowan, orlando-mayorquin, johnny-diaz
description:
A federal agent fired his weapon during an immigration enforcement operation in the Los Angeles area on Wednesday morning, according to the Department of Homeland Security.
Federal agents in tactical gear and carrying long rifles were at the scene, as were sheriff’s deputies.
Holly Mitchell, who represents the area on the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors, said in an interview that she had been briefed on the episode by officials with the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department on Wednesday.
She said she drove there to check on her parents, who live in the area, and to protest the federal agents.
She waved a large Mexican flag she said she had used at a previous “No Kings” protest in Los Angeles.
text:
A federal agent fired his weapon during an immigration enforcement operation in the Los Angeles area on Wednesday morning, according to the Department of Homeland Security.

The agency said in an emailed statement that its agents were conducting an operation around 7 a.m. to arrest a man who they said had been “involved in a human smuggling operation.”

The department said that the man, Eduardo Moran Carballo, of El Salvador, had attempted “to evade arrest” and then “rammed law enforcement” with his vehicle. The agency said a federal agent had “fired defensive shots” and feared for his safety. It did not specify which Department of Homeland Security agency the officer worked for.

Mr. Carballo was not hit or injured in the shooting, the department said. A U.S. Customs and Border Protection officer was injured, according to the Homeland Security Department, which did not elaborate on the nature of his injuries or state his condition. Agents took Mr. Carballo into custody.

The department said the operation took place in Compton, Calif., south of Los Angeles, but a local official said it happened in Willowbrook, an unincorporated area of Los Angeles County.

“This situation is evolving, and more information is forthcoming,” the department said, adding that Mr. Carballo had two prior arrests on accusations of “inflicting corporal injury on a spouse or cohabitant.”

Hours after the incident, the wreckage of a gray BMW sports car that crashed was on the street near a curb, its airbags deployed and both doors open. Federal agents in tactical gear and carrying long rifles were at the scene, as were sheriff’s deputies. Helicopters hovered overhead as protesters, shouting obscenities at the masked federal agents, began to arrive.

The Trump administration’s national immigration crackdown first ramped up in Southern California — and particularly in many of the heavily Latino suburbs of Los Angeles County — last summer.

Holly Mitchell, who represents the area on the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors, said in an interview that she had been briefed on the episode by officials with the Los Angeles County Sheriff’s Department on Wednesday.

Ms. Mitchell said that a Border Patrol and Immigration and Customs Enforcement task force action led to a “vehicle pursuit,” which ended at around 7:30 a.m. in Willowbrook. She said she was told that one round was fired, and that no one was hit. The Sheriff’s Department helped to secure the scene, she said, but emphasized that county law enforcement officers were not involved in the immigration enforcement action.

Ms. Mitchell, whose vast district includes many neighborhoods where working-class Latino families have lived for generations, said that the episode on Wednesday appeared to have been carried out with “the same kind of recklessness and lack of regard for basic human rights and true public safety” that she has seen from federal agents for months.

The car chase on Wednesday, she said, took place during the morning rush hour, just as families were taking children to school. She added that the use of lethal force by agents, both in Los Angeles and in other cities, is troubling.

“Fortunately no one was killed,” she said. “It was by sheer luck — I assume they didn’t intend to miss when they fired their firearm, so we were blessed today.”

Ms. Mitchell urged constituents to continue to document any activity they see, if they can do so safely. She echoed officials in Minnesota who have said that such documentation of interactions between federal agents and members of the public could be important evidence in future court cases over the federal government’s tactics.

Rosa Enriquez, 39, who lives in nearby South Gate, was among dozens of people who gathered at the scene. She said she drove there to check on her parents, who live in the area, and to protest the federal agents. She waved a large Mexican flag she said she had used at a previous “No Kings” protest in Los Angeles.

“We’re in Compton,” she said. “We’re so used to living life being cautious, being careful, and this is what we fear the most.”

Kitty Bennett contributed research.

name: Agencies
title: Morristown ICE raid: donations pour in for detainees' legal defense - Daily Record
description:
Donors have raised $120,000 for their legal defense as they face deportation.
When he told the ICE officials his daughter was upstairs, "They said, 'We're not here for your daughter.
Online fundraisers Murphy has cosponsored an online fundraiser for her neighbor's legal defense along with a family cousin of Mancia Rodriguez, Rosa Portillo.
Another fundraiser has collected more than $94,000 for the legal defense of Juan David Mendoza, a Morristown High School senior who was among the detainees.
Mendoza, 17, "was taken by ICE without warning, leaving his family shocked and terrified," the organizers of the fundraiser wrote.
text:
While the federal Department of Homeland Security continues to withhold the identity of most of the 11 people arrested by ICE agents in Morristown on Jan. 11, the community has rallied to support at least two of them in a big way.

Online fundraisers have identified two of the residents arrested that Sunday morning along Speedwell Avenue —including a Morristown High School senior. Donors have raised $120,000 for their legal defense as they face deportation.

Adonay Mancia Rodriguez went to pick up a takeout food delivery at the front door of his apartment building when Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents arrested him, leaving his 6-year-old daughter alone, a family friend said. The Honduran national came to the U.S. in 2013 and works in town as a chef, according to Cathleen Murphy, a Morristown teacher and neighbor of Mancia Rodriguez's family.

He remains in custody at the Elizabeth Contract Detention Facility, ICE records show.

"He came here as a refugee when he was 17 years old," said Murphy, who said she was "acting as [the family's] advocate during this time."

"He never received a follow-up mailing for his immigration process," she said. "He has a case to get his green card and everything. He just didn't receive the mailing to go to court. So he never followed up with the process and then that's what led to the deportation order, we guess."

When he told the ICE officials his daughter was upstairs, "They said, 'We're not here for your daughter. We're here for you,'" Murphy added. "They did not send anybody to check on her or coordinate with local police or anything. They just took him to the car."

The girl was in the apartment upstairs for about an hour until she realized something was wrong, Murphy said.

6-year-old left alone

"So she gathered up her things, her coat, her shoes and her tablet, and she went out on the street," she said. "She waited for a woman who came walking up the street and she said, 'I don't know where my dad is.' The woman was able to use the tablet to contact the family. Her mother was working at Walmart at the time."

"The little girl is absolutely traumatized," Murphy said.

Mancia Rodriguez's family has been allowed to visit him in detention, and an attorney is working on the case.

"We're waiting to hear this week if the judge will accept the motion to reopen his case to become a citizen. or a resident," Murphy said.

In a Jan. 15 response to emailed questions, three days after the raid, the Department of Homeland Security confirmed the arrests of 11 "illegal aliens, several with felony offenses" in the Morristown operation.

Others "took advantage of the Biden administration’s open border crisis," Tricia McLaughlin, a DHS assistant secretary, said in the email.

The message did not identify the detainees nor provide details about the alleged offenses.

Online fundraisers

Murphy has cosponsored an online fundraiser for her neighbor's legal defense along with a family cousin of Mancia Rodriguez, Rosa Portillo. It had exceeded $26,000 as of late on Jan. 20.

"He first came to the country as a refugee and has been living and working in Morristown for over a decade," Portillo wrote.

"He is a hard worker with no criminal record whatsoever who is just trying to provide for his family. He has a huge family here that is devastated, but most of all is his daughter, who is inconsolable. They are very close and all she wants is to have him back."

Another fundraiser has collected more than $94,000 for the legal defense of Juan David Mendoza, a Morristown High School senior who was among the detainees. Mendoza, 17, "was taken by ICE without warning, leaving his family shocked and terrified," the organizers of the fundraiser wrote.

Organizers have yet to respond to messages from the Daily Record, but according to an update on the fundraising page, a district judge ordered the teen's release on Jan. 15 and he is currently represented by legal counsel. Efforts to reach the family were unsuccessful.

In a follow-up email from DHS on Jan. 20, McLaughlin said Mendoza was "an illegal alien from Honduras" who had entered the U.S. in 2024. "He is an adult," McLaughlin added.

"All individuals are currently detained, and either in removal proceedings or in the process of being removed from the United States in accordance with U.S. immigration law," she said.

“We encourage all illegal aliens to use the CBP Home app to take control of their departure. The U.S. taxpayer is generously offering illegal aliens $1,000 and a free flight home.”

name: Litigation
title: Advocates, Democrats rally in Albany for $175 M legal defense against ICE - NEWS10 ABC
description:
They want the state to refuse cooperation with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to offer legal aid to New Yorkers who are detained.
“We are here at a pivotal moment, a moment in time where our state and our country is at a crossroads,” said Murad Awawdeh, president and CEO of the New York Immigration Coalition.
The coalition also rallied for the Building Up Immigrant Legal Defense Act.
The BUILD Act would fund infrastructure in legal deserts, rural and remote regions where immigration services are historically scarce compared to the state average.
While New York City has robust legal aid networks, the BUILD Act would help develop rural and upstate regions where immigration services are scarcer.
text:
ALBANY, N.Y. (NEXSTAR) — Advocates and Democratic elected officials rallied at the Million Dollar Staircase on Wednesday, demanding Governor Kathy Hochul and the legislature pass bills that shield immigrant from federal enforcement. They want the state to refuse cooperation with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement to offer legal aid to New Yorkers who are detained.

“We are here at a pivotal moment, a moment in time where our state and our country is at a crossroads,” said Murad Awawdeh, president and CEO of the New York Immigration Coalition. “Do we want to continue being a democracy, or do we want to allow a fascist, authoritarian dictator to take us in a different direction?”

The coalition wants the governor to include $175 million in her Fiscal Year 2027 executive budget to pay for the legal services of immigrants facing deportation. That’s because, unlike in criminal court, people in civil immigration court aren’t guaranteed a lawyer.

That’s why lawmakers at the rally pushed for the Access to Representation Act. That bill, S141/A270, would establish the right to legal counsel for those making less than 200% of the federal poverty line—about $31,000 for a single person, $42,000 for a couple, and $64,000 for a family of four—when they’re involved in removal proceedings.

Proponents cited a statistic that immigrants with lawyers are up to two-and-a-half times likelier to win their cases. “Immigration court has as much due process as traffic court, it has been said, but with outcomes as grave as the death penalty,” said Catharine Grainge from the Jericho Road Community Health Center in Buffalo.

Grainge, an attorney, recounted a frantic 72-hour window where she drafted a 300-page motion to save a client from immediate deportation, a technical feat that probably would be impossible for unrepresented immigrants.

Proponents cited a New York City Comptroller report estimating that universal legal representation would put $8.4 billion in savings and revenue in the government’s coffers.

The coalition also rallied for the Building Up Immigrant Legal Defense Act. The BUILD Act, S4538/A2689, would create a grant program to recruit and train lawyers, social workers, and community navigators to handle increasing immigration caseloads.

The BUILD Act would fund infrastructure in legal deserts, rural and remote regions where immigration services are historically scarce compared to the state average. While New York City has robust legal aid networks, the BUILD Act would help develop rural and upstate regions where immigration services are scarcer. The legislation is supposed to give attorneys more time to work on complex litigation.

Ralliers also promoted the New York for All Act, S2235A/A3506A, prohibiting state and local officers—including police and probation officers—from using tax dollars or resources to help immigration agents.

Supporters say ICE increasingly uses local police as deportation agents, eroding public trust by making New Yorkers afraid to report crimes, call for emergency services, or go to school. “We are not going to let you come into our communities to terrorize our neighborhoods, to divide our families, and to devastate our economies,” said State Sen. Andrew Gounardes, a Democrat from southern Brooklyn.

The coalition offered more statistics. Between January and July of 2025, they said, ICE detained almost 5,000 New Yorkers—more than in all of 2024 combined. As of August, almost 340,000 cases were pending in the state’s immigration courts. Assemblymember Catalina Cruz, a Democrat from Queens, described ICE detentions as kidnapping. She cited reports of 36 people dying in ICE custody in 2025.

They also highlighted the economic impacts of immigrants, who paid $31.3 billion in state and local taxes in 2023, while foreign-born residents account for more than a quarter of the workforce and include 190,800 entrepreneurs. “We’ve relied on that money that the immigrants bring every year to make our budget balanced,” Cruz said. “We need to make sure that we are not giving breadcrumbs to immigrants, because it’s frankly insulting.”

While anti-immigration voices maintain that cooperation with federal authorities is necessary to remove criminals and protect public safety, those at the rally disputed that connection between immigration and crime. Assemblymember Karines Reyes, a Democrat from the Bronx, said federal agents target law-abiding residents because they ran out of criminals on day one.

The governor and state legislature are supposed to finalize the state budget by the April 1 deadline, but the state has consistently missed that deadline in recent years.

name: Policy
title: Vance to visit Minneapolis on Thursday amid ICE crackdown - Politico
description:
The trip comes as local and state officials have called for ICE agents to leave the Minnesota after an officer fatally shot 37-year-old Renee Good in her car earlier this month.
Following Good’s shooting, Democratic Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey told the agency to “get the fuck out of Minneapolis,” accusing ICE of “recklessly using power that resulted in somebody dying.” “People are free to come to Minneapolis, including the Vice President — that’s how this country works,” Frey said in a Wednesday statement.
“But if the Vice President actually wanted to help, he should be focused on stopping federal agents from targeting and harming our neighbors in ways that clearly cross constitutional lines.
That’s what Minneapolis wants.” Minnesota Gov.
Walz has repeatedly sparred with President Donald Trump, with federal prosecutors subpoenaing the 2024 Democratic nominee for vice president in the latest clash between the two leaders.
text:
The trip comes as local and state officials have called for ICE agents to leave the Minnesota after an officer fatally shot 37-year-old Renee Good in her car earlier this month. Following Good’s shooting, Democratic Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey told the agency to “get the fuck out of Minneapolis,” accusing ICE of “recklessly using power that resulted in somebody dying.”

“People are free to come to Minneapolis, including the Vice President — that’s how this country works,” Frey said in a Wednesday statement. “But if the Vice President actually wanted to help, he should be focused on stopping federal agents from targeting and harming our neighbors in ways that clearly cross constitutional lines. That’s what Minneapolis wants.”

Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz, a Democrat, has also repeatedly condemned ICE’s operation in the state, which the Department of Homeland Security has sought to tie to a widespread investigation into allegations of government program fraud involving some Somali Americans.

In the wake of the shooting, DHS Secretary Kristi Noem doubled down on the need for a heightened presence of federal law enforcement, vowing that “hundreds more” officials would be deployed to Minnesota in addition to the more than 2,000 agents already there.

The Minnesota Department of Public Safety announced Saturday that the state’s National Guard had been “mobilized and are staging to support local law enforcement and emergency management agencies” at Walz’s direction.

Walz has repeatedly sparred with President Donald Trump, with federal prosecutors subpoenaing the 2024 Democratic nominee for vice president in the latest clash between the two leaders. In a Tuesday statement, Walz called the investigation into him “a partisan distraction,” accusing the Trump administration of pursuing “baseless legal tactics aimed at intimidating public servants standing shoulder to shoulder with their community.”

name: Agencies
title: Congressman Tries to Cut Pay of ICE Prosecutor with Racist X Account to $1
description:
Three members of the U.S. House of Representatives, including Veasey, wrote letters to ICE and DHS demanding information and investigation.
Named for Democratic politician William S. Holman, the rule has been instated and rescinded over the decades.
That same year, some Republicans considered using the rule to derail a now-abandoned special counsel investigation into Donald Trump, though the maneuver was never deployed.
“The amendment before you is simple, and it’s narrow,” Veasey said at the hearing.
“It sends a clear message that we are not going to fund this man’s salary, and that Congress will not fund hate.
text:
As a new Department of Homeland Security (DHS) funding bill works its way through Congress, Congressman Marc Veasey, a Democrat who represents part of Dallas, introduced an amendment in committee Wednesday aimed to reduce the salary of James Rodden, an Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) assistant chief counsel who acts as a prosecutor for ICE in immigration court in Dallas, to $1.

In February of last year, the Texas Observer reported that Rodden operates a white supremacist X account named GlomarResponder, based on an overwhelming number of biographical details that the Observer matched through publicly available documents, other social media activity, and courtroom observation. Three members of the U.S. House of Representatives, including Veasey, wrote letters to ICE and DHS demanding information and investigation. In response, ICE sent a letter to Veasey stating it would address the matter and that such internal investigations can take up to 120 days, but it has otherwise not provided any information.

Veasey’s amendment came a week after the Observer reported that Rodden, who was apparently pulled from federal immigration court schedules following the Observer’s reporting last February, had returned to immigration court in Dallas.

“[Rodden’s] statements are disgusting, and they are dangerous, and regardless of if you are a Democrat or a Republican, they should be disqualifying for anyone entrusted with power in the United States government,” Veasey said during Wednesday’s House Rules Committee hearing. “If Congress does nothing, if the committee does nothing, then we’re sending the message that this type of behavior is tolerable, that accountability is optional, and that white supremacy can continue to be subsidized with taxpayer dollars.”

The GlomarResponder account has over 17,000 followers and has routinely posted hateful statements. In addition to posting that “America is a White nation,” that “‘Migrants’ are all criminals,” and that “All blacks are foreign to my people,” plus apparent praise of Adolf Hitler, the account has also made posts that evoke anti-immigrant violence: “Nobody is proposing feeding migrants into tree shredders,” the account posted in March 2024. “Yet. Give it a few more weeks at this level of invasion, and that will be the moderate position.”

Veasey’s amendment seeking to reduce Rodden’s salary relied upon the Holman Rule, which allows members of the U.S. House to amend appropriations legislation to cut specific programs or reduce the salary of specific federal employees. Named for Democratic politician William S. Holman, the rule has been instated and rescinded over the decades. It was most recently reinstated in 2023 when Republicans retook the majority. That same year, some Republicans considered using the rule to derail a now-abandoned special counsel investigation into Donald Trump, though the maneuver was never deployed.

“The amendment before you is simple, and it’s narrow,” Veasey said at the hearing. “It sends a clear message that we are not going to fund this man’s salary, and that Congress will not fund hate. We can stand by Nazi sympathizers and Hitler supporters, or we can do the right thing and honor the sacrifices of the men and women who died to stop the hateful spread of Nazism.”

This story will be updated with the outcome of Veasey’s amendment.

name: Litigation
title: VICTORY MLFA Secures Federal Court Dismissal for American Muslims for Palestine (AMP)
description:
MLFA celebrates the dismissal of the lawsuit against American Muslims for Palestine (“AMP”) and its leaders, Dr. Osama Abuirshaid and Dr. Hatem Bazian, in the Central District of California on January 20, 2026.
The lawsuit was one of many in which MLFA helps to defend AMP and its leaders against baseless claims.
Judge Mark Scarsi agreed with AMP that “there are no factual allegations raising an inference that AMP was involved” in any conspiracy to harm Plaintiffs.
Despite inflammatory allegations unrelated to the claims, AMP and its leaders continue to see the truth prevail.
They were not, and now they need not be anywhere near these plaintiffs’ baseless claims.” – Christina Jump, Jump Start Legal Justice Center
text:
MLFA celebrates the dismissal of the lawsuit against American Muslims for Palestine (“AMP”) and its leaders, Dr. Osama Abuirshaid and Dr. Hatem Bazian, in the Central District of California on January 20, 2026. The lawsuit was one of many in which MLFA helps to defend AMP and its leaders against baseless claims. Judge Mark Scarsi agreed with AMP that “there are no factual allegations raising an inference that AMP was involved” in any conspiracy to harm Plaintiffs. Despite inflammatory allegations unrelated to the claims, AMP and its leaders continue to see the truth prevail.

MLFA is grateful to Ms. Christina Jump, who began her work on this lawsuit as the Civil Litigation Department Head in MLFA’s Legal Division, and continues to serve as lead counsel for AMP after entering private practice with Jump Start Legal Justice Center. MLFA remains dedicated to helping to represent AMP, with Staff Attorneys Samira Elhosary and Ali Boyd supporting Ms. Jump for the duration of this case. Thanks also go to AMP’s local counsel, Max Schoening of Qureshi Law, for all his help.

“We’re so excited to see AMP vindicated, yet again, from these baseless attacks. Though the lawsuits continue to get creative, we continue to rise to the occasion to protect AMP and allow it to continue its important work educating the US public about the just cause of Palestine.”

– Samira Elhosary, Civil Litigation Staff Attorney:

“I remain honored to lead litigation for AMP, both during my time at MLFA and now as Jump Start Legal Justice Center. Each time we have the opportunity for facts to rise over fear, the federal courts recognize the failures of the lawsuits against AMP. AMP and its officials work hard, and work honestly, and even the plaintiffs couldn’t point to a single fact where AMP committed a violation — as the Judge rightly observed that “there are no allegations that anyone from AMP was anywhere near” the events the plaintiffs claim caused them harm. They were not, and now they need not be anywhere near these plaintiffs’ baseless claims.”

– Christina Jump, Jump Start Legal Justice Center

By the time, by the time you turn around, you are surrounded by uh uh uh ICE agents and they are ready to take you with them. Who is going to take your child when they come back from school? So, because we don't want that to happen in our community, there have been *** lot of community groups coming together. We have created different channels where anything that somebody need, whether it is food or if they want their kids to be put in the school bus on their behalf, there are people on the ground that are going to do that. And uh uh I also wanna add this. I think if the federal government is looking for anyone in this country, so far as the person engaged the system. The federal government knows how to get that person. Without intimidation. Without unleashing terror on our streets. And I would say that we are here and we are willing to support our community as much as we can within the boundaries of the laws. And we are not going to be intimidated. By what is happening on the streets. Thank you. The Somali community in Minnesota has been *** focus of the ice enforcement happening there. Is that also true and important? Well, I don't know. But based on uh photos that were published uh by ICE, it seems the case that it's people of color, not necessarily from Somalia, and I'll discuss that in *** moment. Any other questions? What happens if ICE doesn't comply with the rules like you said they. Did you respond? Obviously this is something that we saw in Minneapolis where they're withholding investigative materials. Well, you can't decide how you're going to cross the bridge till you get there. Right, I, I, I think that's important. I don't like to, to speculate on what's gonna happen. As it's current in Maine seems to be focused, which would indicate to me, and this is the speculation, is that they're functioning on the basis of an actual court warrant. So therefore they've identified *** party they have an address, they know who they're looking for specifically as opposed to this random show me your papers kind of experience. So by doing so, I don't think we're gonna see groupings of agents just patrolling the neighborhood. I think we're gonna get individualized reports from families like I, I received one. Uh, from *** mother saying that her son was arrested at *** grocer, uh, as he came out of work, and I've heard *** rumor that *** hospital saw some of their staff removed, um, but it seems like it's more specific. If that's the case, it appears that ICE may have evolved the way in which they want to engage the community for purposes of enforcement. At the end of the day, we'll see. That's why it's important to document with your witness in the future there may be. Individuals, attorneys, or judicial processes that will need your information. Anything else? Go ahead. Do you have any message for business owners who are not just posting signs, but you know, are very fearful about, you know, carrying on doing new businesses, any reassurances the city can provide that they will be safe and can continue to do commerce? Well, we want them to do commerce. I mean, one of the meetings I participated with, uh, Representatives from the immigrant community, immigrant businesses in the chamber was to set up *** communications channel. We provided them with resources so they'd be clear about their rights and what steps they could take to protect, um. Their employees But it's hard because it's individualized if they're coming for one specific person that's gonna have *** different outcome on the business as opposed to saying you appear to have hired *** number of individuals who may have come from another country we're gonna line them up outside and check their papers. I don't think we're there, to be fair. I think we're in the individualized piece and just to reinforce about the signs in the window. I mean, last I checked, that is the First Amendment. All right. It may not have been perfectly expressed. It may have not taken the tone or language that some could appreciate, but I think. I can't speak to the operation of the mind of the owner of that business, but I think her intent was to. Display her rejection of adverse ICE activity, especially at her place of business. I don't know if I'm gonna communicate to the president. I, I'm gonna communicate to the US attorney. Because he's made, we're made. And I think he has sent *** message that he has *** similar expectation that we do about how the federal government. Will behave as they conduct their lawful duties. Um, I'm one of our city's at-large councilors, um, and I apologize for my casual state of dress as I was out today in the community doing observing like we've asked so many of our community members to do, um, because one of the things that I know as an indigenous person, Um, as I have *** lot of friends and relatives in the Minnesota and Minneapolis area. And so what they have seen is detention of our very own indigenous community members. And so when we were notified that we would have ICE operations here in Portland, one of the most important things to me was to be out in the. Community with our neighbors with our relatives um watching and observing and really trying to reinforce with everyone because this is not day to day business for us is to to observe to show up for your community um to make sure that everyone understands that really immigrants are what make Portland just such an incredible place to be. And what we're not only going to see the social impact and what we all feel when these operations are happening in our neighborhoods, in front of our schools, in front of our grocery stores, is we're also going to see an economic impact. These are now families that will have potentially the primary breadwinner in their household have, has been disappeared. So how are they going to make rent? So we have the potential for. Increase of evictions. We're seeing impacts to our schools for all of these members who are teachers, who are students who are working in the cafeteria or working, um, as bus drivers. If they're not available, our schools are now short-handed. We're seeing that, you know, with businesses around the city, if these people are being disappeared, there's also *** gap. And so these are just such critical members of our community. Um, if we saw that this immigration enforcement was consistent, was following the law, uh, with this administration, I don't think any of us would have the level of anxiety that we're having right now. And so, um, again, I apologize that I am *** little casual today, but it's because I believe if you're going to be of the community, you need to be out in the community, um, and having eyes on. And so, as, uh, Councillor Ali mentioned, there are networks that have been set up for communities to stay in communication with each other to make sure they're checking out. Up on each other, observing, recording so that we have this information to be able to provide back to any of the legal entities if we do see that operations are not being carried out as they're supposed to be according to law. Um, but I'm so proud here to stand with this council and with our mayor and with all of our city staff and our school staff, um, and our school administration to continue to keep Portland operating and being the place that we know that it is, despite what's happening right in this moment. Thank you. I'd also call Councilor Sarah McNevitch, who represents probably the most diverse district in the city. Thank you, Mayor. Uh, that's, uh, Sarah McNevitch, District one, S *** R *** H M I C H N I E W I C Z. Um, as the mayor said, this is the most diverse district in the city and the state. Um, it's the methods that are being employed and the broadcast approach that is so objectionable to so many. Um, there's, there's no legitimate purpose that's being pursued that cannot be achieved through due process. And I think that's the sticking point for *** lot of us. Um, I would encourage everyone to pay attention to what's going on around you, to look out for your neighbors, to know your rights, to know your responsibilities, and to know your resources, to know where to turn, uh, when you want to either report something or to share information or to assist other people, whether they be, you know, walking to school or just looking to have groceries to survive day to day in their homes. Um, That's, that's our strongest asset in Portland is our sense of community and our sense of pride. And our sense of knowing what is right. And that's what this council stands for. That's what I stand for. That's what the mayor stands for. And I know that's what the vast majority of our citizens stand for and what we will continue to support and continue to act on no matter what comes forward in the coming days. Thank you. Thank you, Councilor. Last but not least. Councilor Phillips. Uh, thank you, Mr. Mayor. Regina Phillips, R E G I N *** P H I L L I P S I represent district three. You know, as I sit here with my colleagues, uh, there isn't anything new that I can say to you other than, um, with this, you know, I don't know if there's warrants out there or, you know, whatever. All I know is what I hear is, is that some folks, um, are just being detained just because, right? We're very similar to Minnesota. They're just being detained because they are. My concern is with the children that are being left behind. We have, we have families that are, people, um, men and women, uh, um, mothers and fathers that are literally being dragged away from their children is what I hear. And, You know, if you have *** child, um, that is either in the grocery store or at home with *** parent, they don't know how to use *** cell phone. They don't know how to get in touch with their other parent. They don't know how to get in touch with *** relative. And as we know, ICE is not coordinating with anybody. They're not coordinating with our police department. They're not coordinating with the Department of Health and Human Services to make sure these children are safe. um, and so we have to mobilize because there are kids out there that are literally being dragged away from their parents. And that's the most concerning to me is what is actually happening to those children with their parents are being taken away literally at the gas station or the grocery store or at schools because they just don't have the means. And the ability to reach out to their relatives and say, hey, I'm stuck. I'm here by myself. And then where do they go? Where do they go? Because we know our foster care system is completely and utterly is overwhelmed. And so that's the concerning thing if you have *** warrant. If you want to detain somebody, like the mayor says, there's probably not much we can do about that, but do it in *** manner where children are not left by themselves. That's just cruel. Thank you, Councilor Superintendent. Chair. No, no, both of you. Listen, um One part that can be left behind is When *** city is going through this type of journey. And you, you heard it at the beginning of the conversations with Councilor Phillips. It's just not about what's occurring to the adults. The kids are there and the kids suffer along with us or celebrate along with us or made anxious because they don't understand what adults are actually trying to do. So one of the first persons that called me the morning that we knew ICE was in the city was Superintendent Scola. So, we protect our constituents, they protect our families, and the most important thing that we all agree on, our kids. So I'd I'd like to defer the podium to the chair, Sarah Lentz, and, uh, I'll stand with the councilor. So if you have any questions that are geared to families in the schools, they're here to respond to that, Madam Chair. Thank you. I'm Sarah Lentz, uh, S *** R *** H. Last name L E N T Z, and I'm chair of the board here in Portland. Um, I told, uh, *** reporter this morning *** story about my own child, who, when I picked him up from school, said to me, first off, he said, today my teacher told me there was ice on the playground and we needed to be careful. And I thought that there were people there to get me and my friends. That level of worry and anxiety is what all of our children are carrying as they go into the classroom. And we know that learning doesn't happen when kids are hungry, when they are scared, and when they don't feel safe. And what is happening in our community right now is making our community not feel safe. And that is not OK. As so many counselors have said today, there are other ways to do this. There are other ways that don't impact our kids and their families in the ways that they are feeling impacted right now. And I just want to say thank you to all of the community members, the individuals, and the organizations that are literally working around the clock right now to make sure that our kids have food in their house, that they can get to work or to the bus stop. That they can be connected to legal services and other resources that they need because they are fearful of coming out of their house. These are the impacts that we're seeing on *** daily basis. Our attendance rates are way down. Kids are not coming to school and their families are holding in their houses. So that's where we are. And that's where we're going to stay and we're going to hold the line and do whatever we can as educators and community members to make sure that our schools are safe and predictable spaces for everyone that are there. Yeah, at this point, are you aware of any students, staff, or family members of students who've been detained by ICE in the last few days? I can confirm that there have been people detained, but that's as much as I'm going to share. Can you give us the number? How, how much is attendance now and uh how? What, what percentage of the of the student population is uh minorities or immigrants? Yeah, so I'm happy to give *** little bit of background and then I'll ask the superintendent to give, um, uh, specific numbers on attendance. But in the Portland Public schools, we have 53% or 52% students of color in our district. About *** third of our students are multilingual learners. Um, and we also have about 500 students who are currently housing insecure. Um, so those are just some of the statistics of our, of our students, uh, right now, but I'm happy to turn it over to the superintendent who can talk more about attendance. Uh, good afternoon. Ryan Scallon, R Y *** N S C *** L L O N. Um, attendance varies significantly, um, as the impact is not even across our school community. So as Chair Lentz just shared, we are about 52, 53%, uh, students of color. Um, and we see *** range of attendance impacts. Um, our overall attendance is down more than 5% points, but we have some schools where the attendance drop is closer to 15 to 20%, uh, down. And so there's ***, there's *** wide range of how it's been impacting. Are there any measures being taken to make remote learning available? Any plans in the works to have entire schools go remote if need be? So, we know from the research coming out of COVID, as well as what we see happening in schools, that the safest, best place for students to learn for social reasons, for physical reasons, for academic reasons are in person. So as much as possible, we are planning to maintain in-person learning. The last two days I've been in our schools and I've seen that they continue to make sure that it's *** safe, welcoming place for all of our students. And so as much as possible, we want that to be. It would also not be prudent if we weren't planning for the range of contingencies. And so leadership in our district, including our school leaders, uh, have engaged and have done some planning around the potential for, uh, an online piece, but at this point, our intent is to remain in person. So I haven't heard anything about this, but just want to confirm with you, have you had any, um, any confirmed sightings of ICE agents on or near Cortland public school campuses? So, we have not had any sightings or reports of agents, um, on our, uh, property around schools. Uh, obviously, there is *** lot of information going on around, um, ICE action, and obviously, we are *** small city and with schools throughout the city. And so there's nothing that is in the immediate vicinity, but certainly in the neighborhood. If there's nothing else, we can all say goodnight.

"A war of terror that is being waged on our city." Portland's mayor, city leaders address ICE activity in Maine

The comments come as Operation Catch of the Day is underway in the state

The U.S. Department of Homeland Security launched "operation catch of the day" in Maine on Tuesday, calling it an immigration enforcement effort across the state targeting the "worst of the worst criminal illegal aliens."Portland Mayor Mark Dion and members of the Portland City Council spoke Wednesday afternoon about the presence of ICE in Maine. Watch the entire press conference in the media player above.Dion said immigration law is lawful, but he has concerns about the tactics used by ICE."This council doesn't stand apart from our immigrant communities, but rather, we stand with them," Dion said.Dion said people need to respect law enforcement, but encouraged them to be the best possible witness and document what they see. "I want everyone safe. Interrupting law enforcement is a risk... that could lead to outcomes no one wants," he said.Dion said he did not know an exact number of arrests that had happened in Portland as part of the operation."This is a war of terror that is being waged on our city by the federal government," said Councilor Wes Pelletier. He said immigrants in the city are scared to go out, fearing that they will be arrested. He called the actions by federal agents "abductions" and said there was a now a war on the streets.Councilor Pious Ali said people are afraid and scared and they don't know what to expect. "Who is going to take your child when they come back from school?" he said. Ali said the council was ready to support the community, within the bounds of the law, and that they would not be intimidated.Councilor April Fournier said there were both social and economic impacts to the operations in Portland. Councilor Sarah Michniewicz, who represents the most diverse district in the city and the state, said it was their responsibility to stand up for the communities that make their city what it is.She said there are legitimate reasons for immigration enforcement, but there were concerns about the way it was being carried out.Councilor Regina Phillips said she was worried about the children of people who were being detained and left behind. "There are kids out there who are literally being dragged away from their parents," she said. Portland School Board Sarah Lentz said attendance rates in Portland schools are down significantly and that people connected to Portland schools have been detained, but she would not say how many or if they were students, staff or family members."What is happening in our community right now is making our community not feel safe, and that is not okay. As so many counselors have said today, there are other ways to do this. There are other ways that don't impact our kids and their families in the ways that they are feeling impacted right now," said Lentz.DHS said some of the charges those arrested this week in Maine are facing include aggravated assault, false imprisonment, and endangering the welfare of a child.Dion told Maine's Total Coverage on Tuesday that his office has been getting numerous calls and videos about ICE activity in the city.Related Content Operation Catch of the Day is underway in Maine The Westbrook mayor spoke out Wednesday against ICE actions in his city State leaders call on people to "tone down the rhetoric" concerning ICETribal leaders encourage people to carry papersUS Attorney for Maine calls for any protests to remain peaceful

The U.S. Department of Homeland Security launched "operation catch of the day" in Maine on Tuesday, calling it an immigration enforcement effort across the state targeting the "worst of the worst criminal illegal aliens."

Portland Mayor Mark Dion and members of the Portland City Council spoke Wednesday afternoon about the presence of ICE in Maine.

Advertisement

Watch the entire press conference in the media player above.

Dion said immigration law is lawful, but he has concerns about the tactics used by ICE.

"This council doesn't stand apart from our immigrant communities, but rather, we stand with them," Dion said.

Dion said people need to respect law enforcement, but encouraged them to be the best possible witness and document what they see. "I want everyone safe. Interrupting law enforcement is a risk... that could lead to outcomes no one wants," he said.

Dion said he did not know an exact number of arrests that had happened in Portland as part of the operation.

"This is a war of terror that is being waged on our city by the federal government," said Councilor Wes Pelletier. He said immigrants in the city are scared to go out, fearing that they will be arrested. He called the actions by federal agents "abductions" and said there was a now a war on the streets.

Councilor Pious Ali said people are afraid and scared and they don't know what to expect. "Who is going to take your child when they come back from school?" he said.

Ali said the council was ready to support the community, within the bounds of the law, and that they would not be intimidated.

Councilor April Fournier said there were both social and economic impacts to the operations in Portland.

Councilor Sarah Michniewicz, who represents the most diverse district in the city and the state, said it was their responsibility to stand up for the communities that make their city what it is.

She said there are legitimate reasons for immigration enforcement, but there were concerns about the way it was being carried out.

Councilor Regina Phillips said she was worried about the children of people who were being detained and left behind. "There are kids out there who are literally being dragged away from their parents," she said.

Portland School Board Sarah Lentz said attendance rates in Portland schools are down significantly and that people connected to Portland schools have been detained, but she would not say how many or if they were students, staff or family members.

"What is happening in our community right now is making our community not feel safe, and that is not okay. As so many counselors have said today, there are other ways to do this. There are other ways that don't impact our kids and their families in the ways that they are feeling impacted right now," said Lentz.

DHS said some of the charges those arrested this week in Maine are facing include aggravated assault, false imprisonment, and endangering the welfare of a child.

Dion told Maine's Total Coverage on Tuesday that his office has been getting numerous calls and videos about ICE activity in the city.

State leaders call on people to "tone down the rhetoric" concerning ICE

Tribal leaders encourage people to carry papers

US Attorney for Maine calls for any protests to remain peaceful

name: Policy
title: 'A Surrender to Trump's Lawlessness': Democrats Warned Against Giving ICE More Money
description:
"I understand that many of my Democratic colleagues may be dissatisfied with any bill that funds ICE.
I share their frustration with the out-of-control agency," DeLauro said, while also stressing that the bill "is more than just ICE."
Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) said that it "puts no meaningful constraints on the growing lawlessness of ICE, and increases funding for detention over the last appropriations bill passed in 2024."
Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Calif.), one of several Democrats expected to run for president in 2028, also spoke out against the bill, telling NBC News that "it is a surrender to Trump's lawlessness.
Some critics of recent immigration actions have suggested that any Democrat who still supports funding ICE should be primaried.
text:
As congressional negotiators on Tuesday released a proposed spending bill for the US Department of Homeland Security, with the January 30 funding deadline rapidly approaching, critics of President Donald Trump's deadly immigration operations renewed calls for Democrats to oppose any new money for Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

"You can't count on Dem leadership to do much, but you can for sure trust these warriors for democracy to hustle like hell to pass a bipartisan deal to fully fund the Gestapo currently attacking our cities, rather than using this one moment of leverage to try to stop them. Bravo!" quipped progressive organizer Aaron Regunberg on social media.

Since an immigration agent fatally shot Renee Good in Minneapolis earlier this month, congressional Democrats have faced mounting pressure to significantly rein in DHS and its agencies, including ICE and Customs and Border Protection (CBP). While some progressive lawmakers have embraced such calls, neither Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer (D-NY) nor House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D-NY) has shown serious interest in using the appropriations process to that end.

Both Senate Appropriations Committee Vice Chair Patty Murray (D-Wash.) and House Appropriations Committee Ranking Member Rosa DeLauro (D-Conn.) tried to frame the DHS bill released on Tuesday as taking "several steps in the right direction," in the words of DeLauro, who also acknowledged that "it does not include broader reforms Democrats proposed."

"I understand that many of my Democratic colleagues may be dissatisfied with any bill that funds ICE. I share their frustration with the out-of-control agency," DeLauro said, while also stressing that the bill "is more than just ICE." She specifically pointed to funding for the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Transportation Security Administration, and the US Coast Guard.

As a bill summary from Murray's office states, the legislation funds those and "other critical programs Americans count on" while cutting "funding for CBP by $1.3 billion relative to fiscal year 2025, providing $18.3 billion in total."

It also "flat-funds ICE at $10 billion, preventing any growth to ICE's annual budget, and it cuts ICE's enforcement and removal budget," the document details. "The bill provides $949 million (-15%) less in funding for ICE enforcement and removal operations than House Republicans' and $708 million (-11%) less than Senate Republicans’ proposed bills—and $114 million less than the fiscal year 2025 level."

Taking aim at the DHS secretary, Murray said in a statement that "what we have seen from Kristi Noem's Department of Homeland Security is frankly sick and un-American. ICE is out-of-control, terrorizing people, including American citizens, and actively making our communities less safe."

Sometimes, when members of Congress can't strike a deal before a funding deadline, they'll pass a continuing resolution that provides short-term funding to prevent a federal government shutdown and keep up negotiations. However, Murray suggested in a Tuesday statement that a CR is not a viable option because of the $75 billion for ICE included in the One Big Beautiful Bill Act that Trump signed last July.

"ICE must be reined in, and unfortunately, neither a CR nor a shutdown would do anything to restrain it, because, thanks to Republicans, ICE is now sitting on a massive slush fund it can tap whether or not we pass a funding bill," Murray said. "The suggestion that a shutdown in this moment might curb the lawlessness of this administration is not rooted in reality: Under a CR and in a shutdown, this administration can do everything they are already doing—but without any of the critical guardrails and constraints imposed by a full-year funding bill."

Murray also nodded to Republican control of Congress that the November midterms, arguing that "the hard truth is that Democrats must win political power to enact the kind of accountability we need... "If you believe that we should be putting more of our taxpayer dollars towards healthcare and that our immigration enforcement should be focused on actual criminals instead of tear-gassing American children, then we need to speak up again and again—and we must take our fight to the ballot box."

Other Democrats in Congress swiftly rejected the proposal. Sen. Chris Murphy (D-Conn.) said that it "puts no meaningful constraints on the growing lawlessness of ICE, and increases funding for detention over the last appropriations bill passed in 2024."

"I understand Democrats in these negotiations had a hard job—no new budget for DHS is going to cure all the rampant illegality happening within the department. But this bill doesn't put CBP agents back at the border where they belong and doesn't put checks on ICE’s out-of-control arrest and enforcement operations," he explained. "Democrats have no obligation to support a bill that not only funds the dystopian scenes we are seeing in Minneapolis but will allow DHS to replicate that playbook of brutality in cities all over this country."

The leadership of the nearly 100-member Congressional Progressive Caucus last week vowed to "oppose all funding" for US immigration enforcement in any upcoming appropriations bills without substantial reforms. CPC Chair Emerita Pramila Jayapal (D-Wash.) made her personal opposition to Tuesday's proposal clear, declaring that "it simply does not meet the moment we face in this country with the lawlessness" of ICE and CBP agents.

"We have seen ICE and DHS descending on cities across this country, racially profiling, and rounding up immigrants and US citizens alike—many of whom have committed no crimes," said Jayapal, an immigrant herself. "We have watched in horror as they have dragged people out into the snow and as they have shot and killed US citizens. As they foment this terror and chaos on our streets, 37 people have died in ICE custody since Trump came back to office."

"Meanwhile, across the country, over 70,000 people are being incarcerated in immigration jails run by private, for-profit prison contractors and being denied due process and bond hearings in Trump's mass detention effort that dozens of judges have said is not lawful," she stressed. "All of this is dangerous—not just for immigrants but for every single American worried about the erosion of Constitutional rights."

Rep. Ro Khanna (D-Calif.), one of several Democrats expected to run for president in 2028, also spoke out against the bill, telling NBC News that "it is a surrender to Trump's lawlessness. I will be a strong no and help lead the opposition to it."

The progressive group Indivisible has urged voters across the country "to light a fire under Democrats to demand they use their leverage on the DHS appropriations bill to rein in ICE and deny the Trump regime one penny more for its mass deportation machine."

"While most Republicans continue to rubber-stamp Trump's atrocities, some are becoming bolder in criticizing ICE's lawlessness and pattern of shredding constitutional protections," notes the group's webpage on reining in ICE. "The louder we are and the more we organize our communities to take action, the harder it will be for Republicans to continue backing Trump's terror campaign."

"Democrats need to stop whining about the limits of minority power and start fighting as hard as their constituents are to stop this regime’s mounting atrocities," the Indivisible page adds. "We're not accepting excuses, and we will hold every member of Congress accountable who chooses complicity and cowardice over courage."

Some critics of recent immigration actions have suggested that any Democrat who still supports funding ICE should be primaried. Philadelphia Inquirer columnist Will Bunch made that case Tuesday, writing that "the lack of appetite for utterly dismantling the DHS regime—despite its culture of violence and disrespect for law-abiding refugees—reminds too many voters of the cowardice that branded the Dems as losers in the first place."

"Dismantling the ICE regime needs to be the floor, not the ceiling" he added, "and any Democrat in Congress who doesn't get with the program can—and should—be replaced in the primaries to avoided another debacle with alienated or apathetic voters in November."

name: Human Rights
title: Shots fired in Willowbrook during DHS operation targeting human smuggling suspect
authors: Jonathan Lloyd, Nyree Arabian, Jonathan Lloyd, Nyree Arabian
description:
A federal agent opened fire Wednesday morning in the southern Los Angeles County community of Willowbrook during an immigration enforcement operation that resulted in a human smuggling suspect being taken into custody, the Department of Homeland Security said.
Shots were fired by a federal agent as officers were attempting to detain the target of the operation, authorities said.
"In a dangerous attempt to evade arrest, this criminal illegal alien weaponized his vehicle and rammed law enforcement," the DHS spokesperson said.
The criminal illegal alien was not hit and attempted to flee on foot.
Federal agents have been in the Los Angeles are conducting immigration enforcement operations for months as part of President Trump's mass deportation campaign promise.
text:
A federal agent opened fire Wednesday morning in the southern Los Angeles County community of Willowbrook during an immigration enforcement operation that resulted in a human smuggling suspect being taken into custody, the Department of Homeland Security said.

No one was struck by gunfire in the shooting, reported at about 7:30 a.m. in the 2400 block of 126th Street, but federal authorities said a Customs and Border Patrol officer was injured. Details about the injury were not immediately available.

The Los Aneles County sheriff's Department said federal agents were conducting an operation in the area when there was a brief pursuit that ended in a crash. Video from NewsChopper4 showed a BMW with front-end damage and what appeared to be deployed air bags.

Shots were fired by a federal agent as officers were attempting to detain the target of the operation, authorities said.

A Department of Homeland Security spokesperson said DHS officers were conducting the targeted operation early Wednesday in nearby Compton to "arrest a violent criminal illegal alien from El Salvador." The agency said William Eduardo Moran Carballo was part of a human smuggling operation and has two prior arrests for inflicting corporal injury on a spouse or cohabitant.

An immigration judge issued a final order of removal from the United States in 2019, the DHS said. NBC4 Investigates is attempting to obtain more information about Carballo's criminal record.

"In a dangerous attempt to evade arrest, this criminal illegal alien weaponized his vehicle and rammed law enforcement," the DHS spokesperson said. "Fearing for his life and safety, an agent fired defensive shots. The criminal illegal alien was not hit and attempted to flee on foot. He was successfully apprehended by law enforcement. The illegal alien was not injured, but a CBP officer was injured.

"These dangerous attempts to evade arrest have surged since sanctuary politicians, including Governor Newsom, have encouraged illegal aliens to evade arrest and provided guides advising illegal aliens how to recognize ICE, block entry, and defy arrest. Our officers are now facing a 3,200% increase in vehicle attacks. This situation is evolving, and more information is forthcoming."

LA County Sheriff's deputies were at the scene to provide traffic control.

Federal agents have been in the Los Angeles are conducting immigration enforcement operations for months as part of President Trump's mass deportation campaign promise. Border crossings have plummeted and Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) arrests have doubled in the past year.
